English title(s): The Opening, the Opening of the Divine Writ, The Essence of the Divine Writ, The Surah of Praise, The Foundation of the Qur'an, andThe Seven Oft-Repeated [Verses][7]
Main theme(s): The fundamental principles of the Qur'an in a condensed form.[8]

English title(s): The Calf, The Cow, The Heifer
Main theme(s):
The necessity of God-consciousness.[8]
The error(s) committed by followers of earlier revelations.[8]
Legal ordinances (ethics, social relations, warfare etc.).[8]
Ibrahim.[8]
Kaaba.[8]
Ayatul Kursi. (v. 255)[9]

English title(s): The Family of Imraan, The House of ʿImrān
Main theme(s):
The human nature of Isa.[8]
The oneness of Allah.[8]
Man’s faith and temptations.[8]
The Battle of Uhud (3 AH).[8]

Unity of the human race and the mutual obligations of men and women towards one another. (v. 1) [8]
Rights of women.[8]
Questions related to family life (including marriage and inheritance).[8]
Peace and war.[8]
Relations of believers with unbelievers.[8]
Striving in the Cause of Allah (Jihad). (v. 95-97) [10]

English title(s): The Food, The Repast, The Table
Main theme(s):
A series of ordinances (incl. Religious rites and social obligations).[8]
Corruption of the original message of the Ingeel by Jews and Christians. (v. 68-77, 116-118) [8]

Human nature of Muhammad. (v. 50) [8]
Oneness and uniqueness of Allah. (e.g. v. 100, 103) [8]
Pre-Islamic superstitions concerning animals. (v. 136ff) [8]

English title(s): The Heights, The Faculty of Discernment
Main theme(s):
The mission of the prophets.[8]
Adam, Hawwa and Iblis. (v. 16-25) [8]
Stories of Nuh, Hud, Salih, Lut, Shuáyb and Musa. (v. 59-171) [8]
Allah's Covenant with humanity. (v. 172) [11]
What happens to those who discard Allah’s message. (v. 175) [8]

The Battle of Badr (2 A.H.).[8]
Doctrine of sacrifice through action.[8]

Problems of war between believers and their enemies.[8]
The expedition to Tabuk (9 A.H.).[8]
Prohibition of intercalation in the Islamic lunar calendar(v. 37) [10]
Those who cannot attain to faith. (v. 124-127) [8]

The revelation of the Qur'an to Muhammad (not Muhammad’s own work). (v. 15-17, 37-38, 94) [8]
References to earlier prophets.[8]
Fundamental tenets of Islam.[8]

The revelation of God’s will through his prophets.[8]
More stories of earlier prophets.[8]
Just dealings between men.[8]
The story of the prophet Joseph (as an illustration of God’s unfathomable direction of men’s affairs).[8]
God’s revelation, through his prophets, of certain fundamental moral truths, and the consequences of accepting or rejecting them.[8]
The revelation of God’s word to all mankind, destined to lead man from darkness to light.[8]

English title(s): The Rocky Tract, The Stoneland, The Rock City, Al-Hijr
Main theme(s): God’s guidance to man through revelation of the Qur'an, which will remain uncorrupted for all times. (v. 9) [8]

God’s creativeness:[8]Manifested in the instincts of the bee.[8]
Culmination: Guidance through his revealed word.[8]

Muhammad’s Night journey from Mecca to Jerusalem.[8]
The children of Israel. (v. 2-8, 101-104) [8]

A series of parables or allegories on the theme of faith in God versus excessive attachment to the life of this world. Including:[8]The men of the cave. (v. 13-20) [8]
The rich man and the poor man. (v. 32-44) [8]
Moses and the unnamed sage. (v. 60-82) [8]
The allegory of ‘Dhu’l-Qarnayn, the Two-Horned One’. (v. 83-98) [8]

The story of Zachariah and his son John, the precursor of Jesus. (v. 2-15) [8]
The story of Mary and Jesus. (v. 16-37) [8]

The guidance offered by God through his prophets.[8]
The fundamental truths inherent in all revealed religions are identical.[8]The story of Moses. (v. 9-98) [8]

The oneness, uniqueness and transcendence of God.[8]
The continuity and intrinsic unity of all divine revelation.[8]Stories of the prophets of old. (v. 48-91) [8]
The believers of all faiths belong to one single community. (v. 92) [8]
The Mecca pilgrimage and some of the rituals connected with it. (v. 25-38) [8]

True faith.[8]
The evidence of the existence of an almighty Creator, and man’s ultimate responsibility before Him.[8]
The unity of all religious communities, broken by man’s egotism, greed and striving after power. (v. 52-53) [8]
The impossibility to believe in God, without believing in life after death.[8]

Mutual relations and ethical rules between men and women.[8]
The mystic parable of the ‘light of God’ ("Verse of Light"). (v. 35) [8]

English title(s): The Criterion, The Standard, The Standard of True and False
Main theme(s):
The purpose of every divine revelation is to provide a stable criterion of true and false.[8]
The humanness of every apostle sent by God to man. (v. 20) [8]
Divine revelation belongs to God’s creative activity.[8]
Man’s weakness, which causes him to reject God’s message and worship power and wealth etc.[8]
The legend of king Solomon and queen of Sheba.[8]

English title(s): The Narrations, The Stories, The Story
Main theme(s): Human aspects of the life of Moses.[8]
The parable of ‘the spider house’, a symbol of false beliefs that are destined to be blown away by the winds of truth. (v. 41) [8]

Predictions of the near victory of the Byzantines [over the Persians] and the Battle of Badr (2 A.H.). (v. 1-7) [8]
God’s ability to resurrect the dead at the end of time, and the people’s ignorance of this.[8]
The story of Luqman, a legendary sage, counselling his son. (v. 12-19) [8]

God's creation.[12]
God's revelation and man's acceptance or denial.[12]
The Day of Judgement.[12]

English title(s): The Clans, The Confederates, The Combined Forces
Main theme(s):
The War of the Confederates (5 A.H.). (v. 9-27) [8]
The relationship between Muhammad and his family.[8]

The insignificance of the knowledge accessible to man. (v. 9) [8]
The story of the people of Sheba, as an example of the impermanence of human power, wealth and glory. (v. 15-20) [8]
Always be conscious of God. (v. 46) [8]

God’s power to create and resurrect.[8]
God’s revelation of his will through his prophets.[8]

Man’s moral responsibility, resurrection and God’s judgment.[8]
To be recited over the dying and in the prayers of the dead.[8]

English title(s): Those Who Set The Ranks, Drawn Up In Ranks, Those Ranged in Ranks
Main theme(s):
Resurrection and the certainty that all human beings will have to answer before God.[8]
Man’s constant need of prophetic guidance.[8]Stories of earlier prophets. (v. 75-148) [8]
Divine guidance and its rejection by those who are lost in fast pride.[8]

The evidence of the existence and oneness of God in all manifestations of nature.[8]
God forgives all sins to him who repents before his death.[8]
Allegories of the Last Hour and the Day of Judgment.[8]
Man’s false pride, worship of false values (wealth, power etc.) and his denial of divine guidance.[8]Stories of earlier prophets.[8]

English title(s): Expounded, Explained In Detail, Clearly Spelled Out
Main theme(s): Man’s acceptance or rejection of divine revelation.[8]

God is undefinable and unfathomable. (v. 11, 16) [8]
All prophets taught the oneness of God, so all believers of all ‘denominations’ should see themselves as ‘one single community’. (v. 13, 15) [8]
The law of cause and effect: In the life to come man will only harvest ‘what his own hands have wrought’ in this world.[8]

English title(s): The Gold Adornments, The Ornaments of Gold, Luxury, Gold
Main theme(s):
To equal anyone or anything with God is sprititually destructive and logically unacceptable.[8]
People’s blind adherence to the faith of their forefathers. (v. 22-23) [8]
Through revelation worldly pride is eventually brought to naught.[12]
The humility with which all human beings will face their final judgment on resurrection. (v. 28) [8]

English title(s): Winding Sand-tracts, The Dunes, The Sand-Dunes
Main theme(s): Warning the disbelievers of their miserable fate, and reassuring the believers of their salvation.

Fighting (qital) in God’s cause.
Instructions for Muslims to be virtuous to their parents.
The Story of Hud and the punishment of that befell his people.
Advising Muhammad to be more patient in delivering Islam
The Truce of Hudaybiyyah (6 A.H.).[8]

English title(s): The Private Apartments, The Inner Apartments
Main theme(s):
Social ethics.[8]Reverence to Muhammad and the righteous leaders after him.[8]
The brotherhood of all believers and all mankind. (v. 10, 13) [8]
The difference between true faith and outward observance of religious formalities. (v. 14 ff.) [8]

Death and resurrection.[8]
God is closer to man than his neck-vein. (v. 16)[12]

English title(s): The Wind That Scatter, The Winnowing Winds, The Dust-Scattering Winds
Main theme(s): Destruction of those who denied the messengers, and a warning for those who deny the truth.
Muhammad’s experience of an ascension to heaven (Mi’raj, including his vision of the Sidrat al-Muntaha, the Lote-Tree of the Extremity). (v. 13-18) [8]

English title(s): The Most Merciful, The Most Gracious
Main theme(s):
Everything will pass away, except the face of God. (v. 26-27)[12]
Description of paradise. (v. 46-78)[10]

English title(s): The Inevitable, The Event, That Which Must Come to Pass
Main theme(s): Description of life in the Hereafter for the believers and the disblievers.

Divorce.[8]
Faith and denial.[8]
Hypocrisy.[8]
The attitude believers should have toward non-believers.[8]

English title(s): The Mustering, The Gathering, Exile, Banishment
Main theme(s): The conflict between the Muslim coummunity and the Jewish tribe of Banu’n-Nadir of Medina.[8]

English title(s): The Examined One, She That Is To Be Examined
Main theme(s): The believers’ relations with unbelievers.[8]
A call to unity between professed belief and actual behaviour.[8]
Obligatory congregational prayer on Friday.[8]
Hypocrisy.[8]

English title(s): The Cheating, The Mutual Disillusion, The Mutual Loss and Gain, Loss and Gain

Main theme(s): Divorce (waiting period, remarriage).[8]
Certain aspects of Muhammad’s personal and family life.[8]

Man’s inability to understand the mysteries of the universe, and his dependence on guidance through divine revelation.[8]
The manifestation of Gods' absolute perfection in creation through the fine tuning of the universe.

English title(s): The Sure Reality, The Laying-Bare of the Truth
The Ways of Ascent, The Ascending Stairways
Main theme(s): The unwillingness to believe, caused by the restlessness inherent in human nature.[8]
The story of Noah.[8]The struggle against blind materialism and the lack of spiritual values.[8]

English title(s): The Jinn, The Spirits, The Unseen Beings
The Enfolded One, The Enshrouded One, Bundled Up, The Enwrapped One
Main theme(s): Loosening the strict regulation on night prayer.[8]

English title(s): The One Wrapped Up, The Cloaked One, The Man Wearing A Cloak, The Enfolded One
Main theme(s):
This short early surah outlines almost all fundamental Qur'anic concepts.
Gods' promise of eternal damnation for the disbelievers.

English title(s): Resurrection, The Day of Resurrection, Rising Of The Dead
Main theme(s): The concept of resurrection.[8]

English title(s): Those Sent Forth, The Emissaries, Winds Sent Forth
Main theme(s): The gradual revelation of the Qur'an.[8]

English title(s): The Great News, The Announcement, The Tiding
Main theme(s):
Life after death.[8]
Resurrection and God’s ultimate judgment.[8]

English title(s): Those Who Tear Out, Those Who Drag Forth, Soul-snatchers, Those That Rise
The Folding Up, The Overthrowing, Shrouding in Darkness
Main theme(s): The Last Hour and man’s resurrection.[8]

English title(s): The Dealers in Fraud, Defrauding, The Cheats, Those Who Give Short Measure
The Rending Asunder, The Sundering, Splitting Open, The Splitting Asunder
The Mansions Of The Stars, The Constellations, The Great Constellations
The Night-Visitant, The Morning Star, The Nightcomer, That Which Comes in the Night
The Most High, The All-Highest, Glory To Your Lord In The Highest
The Overwhelming Event, The Overshadowing Event, The Pall
The Break of Day, The Daybreak, The Dawn
The Glorious Morning Light, The Forenoon, Morning Hours, Morning Bright, The Bright Morning Hours
Main theme(s):
Man’s suffering and God’s justice.[8]
A message of hope and consolation is given to man from Allah's past mercies.
Man is bidden to pursue the path of goodness and proclaim the bounties of Allah.
Prophecy regarding the good future for Muhammad.

English title(s): The Expansion of Breast, Solace, Consolation, Relief, Patient, The Opening-Up of the Heart

Main theme(s): A fundamental moral verity, common to all true religious teachings.[8]

English title(s): The Clinging Clot, Clot of Blood, The Germ-Cell
Main theme(s): The first five verses revealed to Muhammad. (v. 1-5) [8]

English title(s): The Night of Honor, The Night of Decree, Power, Fate, Destiny
Main theme(s): The Night of Laylat-ul-Qadr

English title(s): The Clear Evidence, The Evidence of the Truth
Main theme(s): The Evidence, and the clear truth

English title(s): The Courser, The Chargers, The War Horse
The Striking Hour, The Great Calamity, The Stunning Blow, The Sudden Calamity
The Piling Up, Rivalry in World Increase, Competition, Greed for More and More
Main theme(s): Man’s greed and tendencies.[8]

English title(s): The Time, The Declining Day, The Epoch, The Flight of Time, Success Criteria
The Scandalmonger, The Traducer, The Gossipmonger, The Slanderer

Main theme(s): The Abyssinian attack against Mecca in the year 570 CE, the Year of the Elephant.[8]
The Quraysh, custodians of the Kaaba, should be thankful to God for protecting them from hunger and danger.[12]

English title(s): The Neighbourly Assistance, Small Kindnesses, Almsgiving, Assistance
Main theme(s): The meaning of true worship through sincere devotion and helping those in need.[12]

Spiritual riches through devotion and sacrifice.
Hatred results in the cutting off of all hope.[12]

English title(s): The Disbelievers, The Kuffar, Those Who Deny the Truth
Main theme(s): The correct attitude towards those who reject faith.[12]

English title(s): The Help, Divine Support, Victory, Succour
Main theme(s): The last complete surah revealed before Muhammad’s death.[8]

English title(s): The Plaited Rope, The Palm Fibre, The Twisted Strands
Main theme(s): Allah cursing Abu Lahab and his wife, who was Muhammad's uncle and at the time of the revelation of this verse, Muhammad's brother in law, due to his hostility towards Islam and Prophet Muhammad.[8]

English title(s): Purity of Faith, The Fidelity, Tawheed (Oneness of God), The Declaration of [God's] Perfection
Main theme(s): The oneness of God.[8]

English title(s): The Daybreak, Dawn, The Rising Dawn
Main theme(s): Seek refuge in God from evil of others.[12]
Trust in God's protection from temptations.[12]
